ES - 5.0	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Over the past five years there have been no large or small releases which have resulted in any injuries, property damage or offsite consequences. An incident investigation program is in place at the Facility and incident investigations would be implemented if needed. 

ES - 6.0	THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Rocklin Terminal maintains a written emergency procedure, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The procedures describe the manner of response to a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address notification of local emergency response agencies if a release occurs. Employees receive training in emergency procedures.

The overall emergency procedure program for the Rocklin Terminal is coordinated with the Placer County Emergency Management Program. This coordination involves periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials and industry representatives. The Rocklin Terminal has around the clock communications capability with appropriate Emergency Management Program officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., Placer County Fire). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. The facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements. 

The emergency response program is updated in when necessary based on modifications made to the plant facilities. The Consolidated Emergency Response/Contingency Plan (CCP) was most recently updated on July 19, 2022.

PRE-START-UP SAFETY REVIEW:  The Rocklin Terminal conducts a pre-startup safety review prior to the operating equipment or systems following a modification that requires a change in process safety information. The purpose of the pre-startup safety review is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment in service. 

RMP COMPLIANCE AUDITS:  Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan must be conducted every three years. Plant operations and management personnel participate as audit team members. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to operations or facility management for resolution.

Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings. 

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION:  The Rocklin Terminal has procedures in place that require prompt investigation of incidents that resulted in or could have reasonably resulted in, a fire/explosion, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendation(s) to prevent a recurrence and presents these results to the business management team for resolution. 

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION:  The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. The Facility has implemented procedures regarding employee participation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program.

nal facility staff, and Kiva Energy corporate staff, understand that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program. 

The Rocklin Terminal has a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the process equipment. 

The training program is comprised of the following:

- Periodic refresher training (provided at least every three years),
- Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification,

MAINTENANCE AND MECHANICAL INTEGRITY:  The maintenance program at the Rocklin Terminal is intended to preserve the mechanical integrity of the process equipment to minimize the potential for an accidental release. The Rocklin Terminal has well established practices and procedures for maintaining process equipment. The basic aspects of this program include 
(1) training, 
(2) developing written procedures, 
(3) performing inspections and tests, and
(4) correcting equipment deficiencies. 

In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process. 

Equipment inspections are conducted on a monthly or quarterly basis. The frequency of the inspection is based upon regulatory framework impacting the particular system or subsystem. 

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE:  The Kiva Energy Rocklin Terminal employs a change management system that requires changes to various systems or items, such as process equipment, technology, procedures and other facility functions, be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. ES - 4.0	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements.

SAFETY INFORMATION:  Kiva Energy keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain a safe operating process. These documents address chemical properties. Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure. Treatment considerations is provided in safety data sheets (SDS's).

Kiva Energy also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the safe normal operations and emergency shutdown of the process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure ratings, temperature ratings and electrical rating of equipment.

PROCESS HAZARDS ANALYSIS:  Kiva Energy conducted a hazard review of the operations at the Rocklin Terminal. The hazard review employed the Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOPS) methodology and a Checklist method analysis. The plant operator and operations management identified and evaluated hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and the team made recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.

OPERATING PROCEDURES:  The Rocklin Terminal maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations such as:
(1) start­up, 
(2) normal operations, 
(3) temporary operations, 
(4) emergency shutdown, 
(5) normal shutdown, and 
(6) initial startup of a new process. 

These procedures provide guidance for experienced operators and also provide the basis for training new operators. Operating procedures include applicable safety precautions that must be taken in the operation of the facility. The procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate. The review and certification process involves both operators and technical staff.

ES - 3.0	THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO
The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario were evaluated for each of the regulated processes. The detailed results of the evaluation are provided in the Risk Management Plan (RMP). Administrative controls limit the tank fill capacity to in accordance with NFPA 58 7.4.3.2(B).

WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO. The worst-case release scenario is the release of propane from a bank of six (6) storage bullets when filled to the greatest amount . The scenario assumes a complete release of 645,660 pounds of propane gas. The pressure wave (with an endpoint of 1 pound per square inch gauge over atmospheric pressure) would extend 0.7 miles (1.1 kilometers). The pressure wave could reach the residential neighborhood located to the southwest of the site as well as the Placer County government center located to the east of the site. There are no sensitive receptors within this blast zone. An estimated total of 1240 nearby residents could be impacted by a blast. 

ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO. The alternative release scenario based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident) is a catastrophic release from a full-sized (10,000 gallon water capacity), tanker truck. This scenario assumes that the tanker leaks from the bottom mounted entry valve and that the entire contents of the truck are released to the atmosphere. The alternative release scenario would produce a pressure wave with an endpoint of 1 pound per square inch gauge over atmospheric pressure that would extend 0.2 miles (0.32 kilometers). Accidental Release Prevention and Response

The Rocklin LPG Terminal has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the facility's processes.  It is the practice of Kiva Energy, LP Terminal LLC to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of substances.  However, if a release does occur, trained personnel will respond to, control and contain the release.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY (19 CCR 2745.3)

ES - 1.0	FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY
The owners, management, and employees of Kiva Energy - LP Terminal, LLC Rocklin (Rocklin Terminal) located at 1545 Nichols Drive, Rocklin, California in Placer County, are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of odorized, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG, propane). If an accidental release should occur, the facility staff are prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Consolidated Emergency Response/Contingency Plan (CCP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.

ES - 2.0	FACILITY INFORMATION
The Facility is a bulk, hydrocarbon storage and handling facility that receives LPG by rail cars and trucks. The liquefied petroleum gas is stored in the facility's 18 aboveground, pressurized storage tanks prior to being loaded into DOT approved delivery trucks (including those owned by Kiva Energy as well as third-party distributors).
